qas.question: How did Nicholas Lezard describe post-punk?
Which artists were influential in post-punk?
Which writers helped to influence the post-punk movement?

answers.text: William S. Burroughs and J.G. Ballard

qas.question: What was an intellectual focus of post-punk?
How did the post-punk movement feel about big business?
What was Nicholas Lezard's description of post-punk?
Where did post-punk ram its appropriation of ideas into?
What tradition could be found in works by Captain Beefheart and David Bowie?
What intellectual movement informed and influenced a variety of post-punk artists?
Why did many post-punk artists produce and release their own music?
What does L.G Ballard describes post-punk  as?
What did artists want to make a distinction between?

plausible_answers.text: literature, art, cinema, philosophy, politics and critical theory

qas.question: What disciplines appropriated ideas from post-punk?

plausible_answers.text: William S. Burroughs and J.G. Ballard

qas.question: What writers were influenced by the post-punk movement?
What culture did journalists not participate in?

plausible_answers.text: a fusion of art and music

qas.question: How did Nicholas Lezard  refuse to describe post-punk?
Which artists did not influence post-punk?
What was not an intellectual focus of post-punk?
Why did post-punk artists never produce and release their own music?
Who was not an important element of the culture?

context: Nicholas Lezard described post-punk as <a5_0><b10_0>"<b15_0>a <a0_0>fusion of art and music<b15_0/><a0_0/>"<a5_0/>.<b10_0/> The era saw the robust appropriation of ideas from <b12_0>literature, art, cinema, philosophy, politics and critical theory<b12_0/> into <a6_0>musical and pop cultural contexts<a6_0/>. Artists sought to refuse the common distinction between <b11_0>high and low culture<b11_0/> and returned to the <a7_0>art school<a7_0/> tradition found in the work of artists such as <a1_0><b16_0>Captain Beefheart and David Bowie<b16_0/><a1_0/>. Among major influences on a variety of post-punk artists were writers such as <a2_0><b13_0>William S. Burroughs and J.G. Ballard<b13_0/><a2_0/>, avant-garde political scenes such as Situationism and Dada, and intellectual movements such as <a3_0><a8_0><b17_0>postmodernism<b17_0/><a8_0/><a3_0/>. Many artists viewed their work in explicitly political terms. Additionally, in some locations, the creation of post-punk music was closely linked to the development of efficacious subcultures, which played important roles in the production of art, multimedia performances, fanzines and independent labels related to the music. Many <b14_0>post-punk<b14_0/> artists maintained an <a4_0><a9_0><b18_0>anti-corporatist<b18_0/><a9_0/><a4_0/> approach to recording and instead seized on alternate means of producing and releasing music. <b19_0>Journalists<b19_0/> also became an important element of the culture, and popular music magazines and critics became immersed in the movement.
